clinical_study.brief_title: Investigation of the Prevalence of Hepatopulmonary Syndrome in Cirrhosis Patients Caused by Hepatitis B in Western China
clinical_study.official_title: Investigation of the Prevalence of Hepatopulmonary Syndrome in Cirrhosis Patients Caused by Hepatitis B in Western China

brief_summary.textblock: to investigate the prevalence of hepatopulmonary syndrome in cirrhosis patients caused by Hepatitis B in western China

detailed_description.textblock: Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS) occurs in approximately 4%-29% of cirrhotic patients and influences mortality. China has 100 million Hepatitis B virus (HBV) carriers and Chronic HBV infection is well-recognized risk factor for cirrhosis.But little is known about the prevalence of HPS in cirrhosis patients caused by HBV in western China. The aim of this study was to investigate the HPS incidence, and the signs, symptoms, arterial blood gas, and BMP9 in the serum of the patients.

primary_outcome.description: through the ultrasound to evaluate the imagine of cardiac cavity after intravenous injection of agitated saline
arterial blood gas analysis was performed through the radial artery.
The medical history was collected through consultation.
spider angioma was examined by inspection
liver palms was examined by inspection
oxygen saturation was examined by pulse oximetry

secondary_outcome.measure: the content of bone morphogenetic protein (BMP9) in the patients with and without HPS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 4 to 6 months after the study completion
secondary_outcome.description: the content and expression of BMP9 were determined by immunohistochemistry.

secondary_outcome.measure: micro ribonucleic acid 144 (miR144), micro ribonucleic acid 200 (miR200) in the patients with and without HPS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 4 to 6 months after the study completion
secondary_outcome.description: the content and expression of BMP9 were determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

study_pop.textblock: Patients were selected with cirrhosis caused by HBV including Southwest Hospital, the first affiliated hospital of Chongqing Medical University, the People's hospital of Rongchang district and Qijiang District people's hospital
